meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's your boy here, ready to dive into the world of Braid: Anniversary Edition. Now, I know what you're thinking - another remaster, another review. But fear not, young gamers, for this review promises to be a wild ride full of humor, wit, and just a dash of self-deprecation (because, let's be real, who doesn't love a little bit of self-roasting?).

So, what makes Braid: Anniversary Edition so special? For starters, it's the perfect opportunity to experience this timeless classic for the first time or revisit it after all these years. The visuals have been given a lovely facelift, making it look like a brand new game (minus the fact that you're still playing the same old levels, but more on that later).

Now, I'm not going to lie - I'm a bit of a Braid newbie myself. Okay, fine, I've never played it before. But that's what makes this review so exciting! I get to experience it for the first time alongside you guys. And let me tell you, it's been quite the adventure.

But enough about my personal experiences (or lack thereof). What do the other critics have to say? Well, God is a Geek thinks it's a reminder of how good the original was, while Push Square says it's a great package for newcomers and fans alike. PlayStation Universe, on the other hand, claims that this is the best time to experience Braid in its restored state, while Video Chums simply calls it "both a throwback to simpler times and a reminder that indie devs can rise above if given the opportunity." (Okay, I might have paraphrased that last one a bit).

PlayStation LifeStyle, however, seems a bit more divided. They say that aside from the visual facelift, not much has changed, which might be a bit of a turn-off for some players. And Hobby Consolas simply calls it "the definitive version of a game that everyone should play once in their life."

Now, I'm not going to lie - I love me some good old-fashioned Braid puns (see what I did there?). But seriously, folks, if you're looking for a great indie platformer with challenging puzzles and stunning visuals, look no further than Braid: Anniversary Edition.

And hey, who knows? Maybe one day I'll even get around to playing the original. A grok can dream, right?
